title: Grid spatial data
text: spatialgridr provides functions gridding spatial data; .e. taking raw spatial data getting data grid. package still development. Feel free submit issue bugs suggestions.

title: Grid spatial data
text: can install development version spatialgridr GitHub : spatialgridr three functions: get_boundary(): retrieves boundaries marine terrestrial area, country Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) get_grid(): creates spatial grid get_data_in_grid(): grids spatial data; can also used crop/ intersect polygon data

title: Grid spatial data
text: shows obtain spatial grid grid data using grid.

title: Grid spatial data
text: can obtain grids raster (terra::rast) vector (sf) format. First need polygon want create grid . can retrieve boundaries countries, Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs), oceans, several jurisdiction types using get_boundary(). example get EEZ Pacific island Samoa.
code: #get Samoa's EEZ samoa_eez <- get_boundary(name = "Samoa")  plot(samoa_eez["geometry"], axes = TRUE)

title: Grid spatial data
text: also need provide suitable projection area interested , https://projectionwizard.org useful purpose. spatial planning, equal area projections normally best.  obtain grid sf format can use arguments option = "sf_square" option = "sf_hex" get_grid specify square hexagonal cells. create plot hexagonal grid 10 km wide cells.
code: #equal area projection for Samoa obtained from https://projectionwizard.org samoa_projection <- '+proj=laea +lon_0=-172.5 +lat_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs'  # Create a raster grid with 10km sized cells samoa_grid <- get_grid(boundary = samoa_eez, resolution = 10000, crs = samoa_projection)  #plot the grid terra::plot(samoa_grid) terra::lines(terra::as.polygons(samoa_grid, dissolve = FALSE)) #add the outlines of each cell samoa_grid_sf <- get_grid(boundary = samoa_eez, resolution = 10000, crs = samoa_projection, output = "sf_hex")  plot(samoa_grid_sf)

title: Grid spatial data
text: Now can grid data. Data can raster (terra::rast()) sf format. ’s example using global map seafloor ridges sf format:  another example using raster data, case global cold water coral distribution data pre-cropped Pacific  can also use sf grid created return gridded data sf format:  can also grid sf data contains multiple data features, habitat types. , provide name column feature_names argument get_data_data_in_grid(). creates multi-layer grid. raster data means multiple raster layers sf grids multi-column objects. ’s example using sf data classifies worlds deep oceans (Abyssal plains) 3 categories:  spatialgridr also works grids cross antimeridian (international date line). can set antimeridian = TRUE get_data_in_grid know using grid crosses antimeridian, antimeridian = NULL (default option), function automatically determine grid crosses antimeridian. ’s example using Kiribati’s EEZ grid area.
code: # ridges data for area of Pacific ridges <- readRDS(system.file("extdata", "ridges.rds", package = "spatialgridr"))  #grid the data ridges_gridded <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_grid, dat = ridges)  #plot terra::plot(ridges_gridded) terra::lines(samoa_eez |> sf::st_transform(crs = samoa_projection)) #add Samoa's EEZ #load cold water coral data cold_coral <- terra::rast(system.file("extdata", "cold_coral.tif", package = "spatialgridr"))  #grid the data coral_gridded <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_grid, dat = cold_coral)  #plot terra::plot(coral_gridded) terra::lines(samoa_eez |> sf::st_transform(crs = samoa_projection)) #add Samoa's EEZ #grid the data ridges_gridded_sf <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_grid_sf, dat = ridges)  #plot plot(ridges_gridded_sf) #load the data abyssal_plains <- system.file("extdata", "abyssal_plains.rds", package = "spatialgridr") |>   readRDS()  #grid the data abyssal_plains_sf <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_grid_sf, dat = abyssal_plains, feature_names = "Class")  #plot plot(abyssal_plains_sf) #load the Kiribati EEZ polygon kir_eez <- get_boundary(name = "Kiribati", country_type = "sovereign")  #create a grid for the Kiribati EEZ - Equal area projection obtained from https://projectionwizard.org kir_grid <- get_grid(boundary = kir_eez, resolution = 50000, crs = '+proj=laea +lon_0=-159.609375 +lat_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs', output = "sf_square")  #get abyssal plains classification for Kiribati grid kir_abyssal_plains <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = kir_grid, dat = abyssal_plains, feature_names = "Class") #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched off #> although coordinates are longitude/latitude, st_intersection assumes that they #> are planar #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched on #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries #plot plot(kir_abyssal_plains, border = FALSE)

title: Grid spatial data
text: just want get data area, don’t want grid , can provide sf polygon get_data_in_grid() set raw = TRUE.
code: kir_abyssal_plains_raw <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = kir_eez, dat = abyssal_plains, raw = TRUE) #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout #> all geometries #shift longitude to make it easier to view data plot(kir_abyssal_plains_raw[1] %>% sf::st_shift_longitude(), border = FALSE) samoa_coral_raw <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_eez, dat = cold_coral, raw = TRUE)  terra::plot(samoa_coral_raw)

title: Get boundaries for an area of interest — get_boundary
Get boundaries for an area of interest — get_boundary
text: name character name country region. NULL boundaries type returned. incorrect name input, user given list valid names chose . Ignored type = "high_seas" type character boundary type. Can one : eez: Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ; 200nm). EEZs differ slightly UN Convention Law Sea (UNCLOS) definition archipelagic waters internal waters country included. 12nm: 12 nautical miles zone (Territorial Seas), defined UNCLOS 24nm: 24 nautical miles zone (Contiguous Zone), defined UNCLOS ocean: Global Oceans Seas compiled Flanders Marine Data Centre. Names : "Arctic Ocean", "Baltic Sea", "Indian Ocean", "Mediterranean Region", "North Atlantic Ocean", "North Pacific Ocean", "South Atlantic Ocean", "South China Easter Archipelagic Seas", "South Pacific Ocean", "Southern Ocean". high_seas: defined UN Law Sea: "parts sea included exclusive economic zone, territorial sea internal waters State, archipelagic waters archipelagic State". Note name country_type relevant query: High Seas areas can downloaded. country: country boundaries Natural Earth seas_oceans: Seas, oceans, bays, gulfs, inlets etc. defined Natural Earth marine polygons details marine boundaries can found Marine Regions website, land boundaries (plus "seas_oceans"), Natural Earth website. Note data Natural Earth downlaoded highest resolution (1:10m). country_type character must either country sovereign; ignored type = "high_seas", "ocean" "seas_oceans". countries many territories jurisdiction . example, Australia, France U.K. jurisdiction many overseas islands. Using sovereign returns main country territories, whereas using country returns just main country. details country via rnaturalearth package vignette

title: Get gridded or cropped data from input data — get_data_in_grid
code: # ridges data for area of Pacific ridges <- system.file("extdata", "ridges.rds", package = "spatialgridr") %>% readRDS() # use get_boundary() to get Samoa's Exclusive Economic Zone samoa_eez <- get_boundary(name = "Samoa")  # You need a suitable projection for your area of interest, https://projectionwizard.org is useful for this purpose. If you are doing spatial planning, equal area projections are normally best. samoa_projection <- '+proj=laea +lon_0=-172.5 +lat_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs'  # Create a spatial grid with 5km square cells samoa_grid <- get_grid(boundary = samoa_eez, resolution = 5000, crs = samoa_projection) # Get ridges data, which is vector data in sf format, in the spatial grid ridges_gridded <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_grid, dat = ridges) #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all geometries terra::plot(ridges_gridded)   #Get some raster data on cold water corals for the same spatial grid cold_coral <- system.file("extdata", "cold_coral.tif", package = "spatialgridr") %>% terra::rast() coral_gridded <- get_data_in_grid(spatial_grid = samoa_grid, dat = cold_coral) terra::plot(coral_gridded)

title: Create a spatial grid — get_grid
text: boundary sf object boundary area(s) want grid , e.g EEZ country. Boundaries can obtained using get_boundary() resolution numeric; desired grid cell resolution units (usually metres degrees) crs: sf::st_crs(crs, parameters = TRUE)$units_gdal crs coordinate reference system: numeric (e.g. EPSG code 4326), character (e.g. "+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs"), object class sf sfc. passed sf::st_crs() output character desired output format, either "raster", "sf_square" (vector), "sf_hex" (vector); default "raster" touches logical. TRUE cells touched boundary included, FALSE cells whose center point (centroid) falls within boundary included. Default FALSE.

title: Create a spatial grid — get_grid
text: terra::rast() format grid, cell within boundary set value 1, whereas cells outside NA. sf grids, grid covers boundary area cells can square (output = "sf_square") hexagonal (output = "sf_hex"). default cells whose centroids fall within boundary included grid. include cells touch boundary use touches = TRUE. sf::st_make_grid() used create sf grids. default ordering grid type bottom top, left right. contrast, terra::rast() grid ordered top bottom, left right. preserve consistency across data types, reordered sf grids also fill top bottom, left right.

title: Create a spatial grid — get_grid
code: # use get_boundary() to get a polygon of Samoa's Exclusive Economic Zone samoa_eez <- get_boundary(name = "Samoa") # You need a suitable coordinate reference system (crs) for your area of interest, https://projectionwizard.org is useful for this purpose. For spatial planning, equal area projections are normally best. samoa_projection <- '+proj=laea +lon_0=-172.5 +lat_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs' # Create a grid with 5 km (5000 m) resolution covering the `samoa_eez` in a projection specified by `crs`. samoa_grid <- get_grid(boundary = samoa_eez, resolution = 5000, crs = samoa_projection)
